column1: Baton Rouge ( BAT-ən ROOZH; from French  Bâton-Rouge 'red stick') is the capital of the U.S. state of Louisiana. On the eastern bank of the Mississippi River
column2: it is the parish seat of East Baton Rouge Parish
column3: the most-populous parish in Louisiana. It is the 100th-most populous city in the United States
column4: and second-largest city in Louisiana after New Orleans. It is also the 16th-most populous state capital. As of the U.S. Census Bureau's July 2019 estimate
column5: Baton Rouge had a population of 220
column8: 493 at the 2010 census. Baton Rouge is the center of Greater Baton Rouge
column9: the second-largest metropolitan area in Louisiana
column12: up from 802
column14: 719 in 2015.The city of Baton Rouge is a major industrial
column19: and growing technology center of the American South. It is the location of Louisiana State University
column20: the LSU System's flagship university and the largest institution of higher education in the state. It is also the location of Southern University
column21: the flagship institution of the Southern University System
column22: the only historically black college system in the nation. The Port of Greater Baton Rouge is the 10th-largest in the United States in terms of tonnage shipped
column23: and is the farthest upstream Mississippi River port capable of handling Panamax ships.The Baton Rouge area owes its historical importance to its strategic site upon the Istrouma Bluff
column24: the first natural bluff upriver from the Mississippi River Delta at the Gulf of Mexico. This allowed development of a business quarter safe from seasonal flooding. In addition
column25: the city built a levee system stretching from the bluff southward to protect the riverfront and low-lying agricultural areas. The city is a culturally rich center
column26: with settlement by immigrants from numerous European nations and African peoples brought to North America as slaves or indentured servants. It was ruled by seven different governments: French
column28: and Spanish in the colonial era; the Republic of West Florida
column29: as a United States territory and state
column31: and United States again since the end of the American Civil War.

column1: Human habitation in the Baton Rouge area has been dated to 12000–6500 BCE
column2: based on evidence found along the Mississippi
column4: and Amite rivers. Earthwork mounds were built by hunter-gatherer societies in the Middle Archaic period
column5: from roughly the fourth millennium BCE. The speakers of the Proto-Muskogean language divided into its descendant languages by about 1000 BCE; and a cultural boundary between either side of Mobile Bay and the Black Warrior River began to appear between about 1200 BCE and 500 BCE
column6: a period called the Middle "Gulf Formational Stage". The Eastern Muskogean language began to diversify internally in the first half of the first millennium AD.The early Muskogean societies were the bearers of the Mississippian culture
column7: which formed around 800 CE and extended in a vast network across the Mississippi and Ohio valleys
column8: with numerous chiefdoms in the Southeast
column9: as well. By the time the Spanish made their first forays inland from the shores of the Gulf of Mexico in the early 16th century
column10: by some evidence many political centers of the Mississippians were already in decline
column11: or abandoned. At the time
column12: this region appeared to have been occupied by a collection of moderately sized native chiefdoms
column13: interspersed with autonomous villages and tribal groups. Other evidence indicates these Mississippian settlements were thriving at the time of the first Spanish contact. Later Spanish expeditions encountered the remains of groups who had lost many people and been disrupted in the aftermath of infectious diseases
column15: unknowingly introduced by the first expedition.

column1: French explorer Pierre Le Moyne d'Iberville led an exploration party up the Mississippi River in 1698. The explorers saw a red pole marking the boundary between the Houma and Bayagoula tribal hunting grounds. The French name le bâton rouge ("the red stick") is the translation of a native term rendered as Istrouma
column2: possibly a corruption of the Choctaw iti humma ("red pole"); André-Joseph Pénicaut
column4: published the first full-length account of the expedition in 1723. According to Pénicaut

column1: From there [Manchacq] we went five leagues higher and found very high banks called écorts in that region
column2: and in savage called Istrouma which means red stick [bâton rouge]
column3: as at this place there is a post painted red that the savages have sunk there to mark the land line between the two nations
column4: namely: the land of the Bayagoulas which they were leaving and the land of another nation—thirty leagues upstream from the baton rouge—named the Oumas.The location of the red pole was presumably at Scott's Bluff

column1: Baton Rouge is located on the banks of the Mississippi River in southeastern Louisiana's Florida Parishes region. The city of Baton Rouge is approximately 79 miles (127 km) from New Orleans

column4: Mississippi and 272 miles (438 km) from Houston

column7: and Greater Houston makes it a prominent transportation hub between the metropolitan regions.

The Muslim demographic has grown out of Middle Eastern immigration and African American Muslim missionary work. column1: The city of Baton Rouge and the Parish of East Baton Rouge have been run by a consolidated government since 1947. It combined the City of Baton Rouge government with the rural areas of the parish
column2: allowing people outside the limits of the City of Baton Rouge to use city services. Though the city and parish have a consolidated government
column3: this differs slightly from a traditional consolidated city-county government. The cities of Zachary
column4: Baker
column5: and Central continue to operate their own individual city governments within East Baton Rouge Parish. Under this system
column6: Baton Rouge has the uncommon office of "mayor-president"
column7: which consolidates the executive offices of "mayor of Baton Rouge" and "president of East Baton Rouge Parish". Though Zachary
column9: and Central each have their own individual mayors
column10: citizens living in these three municipalities are still a part of the constituency who can vote and run in elections for mayor-president and metro council.

column1: The mayor-president's duties include setting the agenda for the government and managing the government's day-to-day functions. They are also responsible for supervising departments
column2: as well as appointing the department heads. The mayor does not set the city's public policy because that is the role of the Metropolitan Council. However
column3: the mayor-president does have some influence on the policy through appointments and relationships with Council members.

column1: The current Mayor-President of Baton Rouge is Sharon Weston Broome
column2: a former Louisiana State Legislator. Broome
column4: succeeded Kip Holden
column5: also a Democrat
column8: after defeating Bodi White in a close runoff on December 10
column9: 2016. She served in the Louisiana House of Representatives from 1992 to 2004
column10: and in the Louisiana State Senate from 2004 to 2016. She was elected by the senate to serve as the Senate President Pro Tempore from 2008 to 2016.

column1: When the city and parish combined government
column2: the city and parish councils consolidated to form the East Baton Rouge Parish Metropolitan Council. The Metro Council is the legislative branch of the Baton Rouge government. Its 12 district council members are elected from single-member districts. They elect from among themselves the mayor-president pro tempore. The Mayor-President Pro Tempore presides over the council's meetings and assumes the role of the Mayor-President if the Mayor-President is unable to serve. The council members serve four-year terms and can hold office for three terms.
Joe Delpit

column7: in 2015 was reported as the oldest continually operating business in Baton Rouge.The Metro Council's main responsibilities are setting the policy for the government

column11: two-year postsecondary public community college
column12: established on June 28
column13: 1995. The college settled into a permanent location in 1998.  The college's current enrollment is more than 8
column14: 000 students. The Pennington Biomedical Research Center houses 48 laboratories and 19 core research facilities.

column1: East Baton Rouge Parish Public Schools operates primary and secondary schools serving the city. The city of Baton Rouge is also home to 15 charter schools with a total enrollment of 3800 pupils. One of the latest includes the Mentorship Academy in downtown Baton Rouge
column2: which leverages its location downtown to establish internship opportunities with local businesses as well as provide a high-tech classroom environment to focus on a digital animation curriculum.The East Baton Rouge Parish School System is the second-largest public school system in the state and contains nine U.S. Blue Ribbon schools and a nationally renowned Magnet program. The school system serves more than 42
column3: 850 students and with the help of 6
column4: 250 teachers and faculty
column5: the district has shown growth and increase in its District Performance Score. The East Baton Rouge Parish Public Schools serve East Baton Rouge Parish and has 90 schools with 56 elementary schools

column1: The State Library of Louisiana is in Baton Rouge. The Louisiana Legislature created the Louisiana Library Commission in 1920. This later became the State Library of Louisiana. The State Library provides Louisiana residents with millions of items with its collections
column2: electronic resources
column3: and the statewide network for lending.The East Baton Rouge Parish Library System has 14 local libraries with one main library and 13 community libraries. The main library at Goodwood houses genealogy and local history archives. The library system is an entity of the city-parish government. The system has been in operation since 1939. It is governed by the EBR Parish government and directed by the Library Board of Control. The Baton Rouge Metropolitan Council appoints the seven-member board and then the board appoints a director. According to its website
column4: all branches are open seven days a week to assist the public with reference and information and  computer access.The Louisiana State Archives' Main Research Library is located in Baton Rouge
column5: as well. It houses general history books
column9: and family histories. The library also has a computerized database of more than two million names that has various information about these people including census
column11: and social security filing information.Louisiana State University and the Louisiana State University Law Center have libraries on their respective Baton Rouge campuses. Southern University and A&M College and the Southern University Law Center also have libraries on their respective Baton Rouge campuses.

column18: and The South Baton Rouge Journal. Other newspapers in East Baton Rouge Parish include the Central City News and The Zachary Post.

column1: Baton Rouge is home station to the Louisiana Army National Guard 769th Engineer Battalion
column2: which recently had units deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan. The armory located near LSU has three company-sized units: 769th HSC (headquarters support company); 769th FSC (forward support company); and the 927th Sapper Company. Other units of the battalion are located at Napoleonville (928th Sapper Company); Baker
column3: Louisiana (926th MAC mobility augmentation company); and Gonzales
column4: Louisiana (922nd Horizontal Construction Company).

column1: The 769th Engineer Battalion is part of the 225th Engineer Brigade
column2: which is headquartered in Pineville
column4: at Camp Beauregard. Four engineer battalions and an independent bridging company are in the 225th Engineer Brigade
column5: which makes it the largest engineer group in the US Army Corps of Engineers.

column1: Baton Rouge is also home to 3rd Battalion
column2: 23rd Marine Regiment (3/23)
column3: a reserve infantry battalion in the United States Marine Corps located throughout the Midwestern United States consisting of about 800 marines and sailors. The battalion was first formed in 1943 for service in the Pacific Theater of Operations during World War II
column4: taking part in a number of significant battles including those at Saipan and Iwo Jima before being deactivated at the end of the war. In the early 1960s
column5: the unit was reactivated as a reserve battalion. The battalion is headquartered in Saint Louis
column7: with outlying units throughout the Midwestern United States. 3/23 falls under the command of the 23rd Marine Regiment and the 4th Marine Division. Recent operations have included tours in Iraq and Afghanistan.

column1: The Port of Baton Rouge is the 9th-largest in the United States in terms of tonnage shipped
column2: and is the farthest upstream Mississippi River port capable of handling Panamax ships.

column1: Baton Rouge has three interstate highways: I-10

column2: and I-110 (Martin Luther King Jr. Expressway).

column1: Interstate 10 enters the city from the Horace Wilkinson Bridge over the Mississippi River
column2: curving at an interchange with Interstate 110 southeast
column3: crossing the LSU lakes and Garden District before reaching an interchange with I-12 (referred to as the 10/12 split). It curves further southeast
column4: towards New Orleans as it crosses Essen Lane near the Medical District. It passes Bluebonnet Blvd and the Mall of Louisiana at exit 162
column5: and leaves Baton Rouge after interchanges with Siegen Lane and Highland Road.

column1: Interstate 12 (The Republic of West Florida Parkway) begins in the city at the I-10/I-12 split east of College Drive
column2: and goes east from there
column4: Airline Hwy
column5: Sherwood Forest Blvd
column7: and O'neal Lane before leaving the city when crossing the Amite River.

column1: Interstate 110 (The Martin Luther King Jr. Expressway) stretches 8 miles in a north–south direction from the east end of the Horace Wilkinson Bridge to Scenic Highway in Scotlandville
column2: Louisiana. It passes through downtown
column4: and Baton Rouge Metro Airport before ending at Scenic Highway.

column1: Baton Rouge has two US highways
column2: along with their business counterparts: Airline Highway (US 61) and Florida Boulevard.

column1: US 190 enters the city from the Huey P. Long Bridge
column2: beginning a concurrency with US 61 after an interchange with Scenic Highway
column3: near Scotlandville. Its name is Airline Highway from this interchange to the interchange with Florida Blvd. At this interchange
column4: US 190 turns east to follow Florida Blvd through Northeast Baton Rouge
column5: exiting the city at the Amite River.

column1: US 61 enters Baton Rouge as Scenic Highway until it reaches Airline Highway (US 190). It becomes concurrent with US 190 until Florida Blvd
column2: where it continues south
column3: still called Airline Highway. It passes through Goodwood and Broadmoor before an interchange with I-12. It continues southeast past Bluebonnet Blvd/Coursey Blvd
column4: Jefferson Hwy
column5: and Sherwood Forest Blvd/Siegen Lane before exiting the city at Bayou Manchac.

column1: US 61/190 Business runs west along Florida Boulevard (known as Florida Street from Downtown east to Mid City) from Airline Highway to River Road in downtown. The cosigned routes run from Florida St. north along River Road
column2: passing the Louisiana State Capitol and Capitol Park Complex before intersecting with Choctaw Drive. North of this intersection River Road becomes Chippewa Street and curves to the East. US 61/190 Business leaves Chippewa Street at its intersection with Scenic Highway. The route follows Scenic Highway to Airline Highway
column3: where it ends. North of Airline on Scenic and East of Scenic Highway on Airline is US 61. US 190 is East and West of Scenic on Airline Highway.

column1: According to the 2008 INRIX National Traffic Scorecard
column2: which ranks the top 100 congested metropolitan areas in the U.S.
column3: Baton Rouge is the 33rd-most congested metro area in the country. However
column4: at a population rank of 67 out of 100
column5: it has the second-highest ratio of population rank to congestion rank
column6: higher than even the Los Angeles-Long Beach-Santa Ana metropolitan area
column7: indicating a remarkably high level of congestion for the comparatively low population. According to the Scorecard
column8: Baton Rouge was the only area out of all 100 to show an increase in congestion from 2007 to 2008 (+ 6%). The city also tied for the highest jump in congestion rank over the same period (14 places).Interstate 12 used to have a major bottleneck at O'Neal Lane. The interstate was three lanes wide in each direction to the O'Neal Lane exit
column9: where the interstate abruptly became two lanes in each direction and crossed the narrow Amite River Bridge. This stretch of road
column11: had become notorious for traffic accidents
column12: many with fatalities. In 2007
column13: ten people died in traffic accidents within a three-month period on this section of road. Governor Bobby Jindal and the Baton Rouge legislative delegation
column15: were successful in allocating state and federal funding to widen I-12 from O'neal Lane to Range Avenue (Exit 10) in Denham Springs. The construction was completed in mid-2012 and has significantly improved the flow of traffic. In 2010
column16: The American Reinvestment and Recovery Act provided committed federal funds to widen I-12 from the Range Avenue Exit to Walker
column17: Louisiana. Noticing the significant improvement in commute times
column18: Bobby Jindal further funded widening to Satsuma

column1: Interstate 10 West at Bluebonnet Road also ranked within the top 1000 bottlenecks for 2008
column2: and I-10 East at Essen Lane and Nicholson Drive ranked not far out of the top 1000. A new exit to the Mall of Louisiana was created in 2006
column3: and the interstate was widened between Bluebonnet Blvd and Siegen Lane. However
column4: the stretch of I-10 from the I-10/I-12 split to Bluebonnet Blvd was not part of these improvements and remained heavily congested during peak hours. In response
column5: a widening project totaling at least $87 million began in late 2008. Interstate 10 was widened to three lanes over a five-year period between the I-10/I-12 split and Highland Road. In 2010
column6: the American Reinvestment and Recovery Act provided supplemental funding for this project to extend to the Highland Road exit in East Baton Rouge Parish. Commute times have since plummeted for this section of interstate.Surface streets in Baton Rouge are prone to severe congestion. However
column7: roads are beginning to handle the number of vehicles using them after years of stagnation in road upgrades. Baton Rouge Mayor Kip Holden has instituted an extensive upgrade of East Baton Rouge Parish roads known as the Green Light Plan
column8: geared toward improving areas of congestion on the city's surface streets. With its first project completed in October 2008
column9: it has seen numerous others reach completion as of 2015
column10: with several more under construction and still others yet to break ground.A circumferential loop freeway was proposed for the greater Baton Rouge metro area to help alleviate congestion on the existing through-town routes. The proposed loop would pass through the outlying parishes of Livingston (running alongside property owned and marketed as an industrial development by Al Coburn
column11: a member of President Mike Grimmer's staff)
column12: Ascension
column13: West Baton Rouge
column15: as well as northern East Baton Rouge Parish. This proposal has been subject to much contention
column16: particularly by residents living in the outer parishes through which the loop would pass. Other suggestions considered by the community are upgrading Airline Highway (US 61) to freeway standards in the region as well as establishing more links between East Baton Rouge Parish and its neighboring communities.

column1: The average one-way commute time in Baton Rouge is 26.5 minutes
column2: slightly less than the US average of 27.1 minutes. Interstates 10
column4: which feed into the city
column5: are highly traveled and connected by highways and four-lane roads that connect the downtown business area to surrounding parishes.According to the 2016 American Community Survey
column6: 81.9% of working Baton Rouge residents commuted by driving alone
column9: and 2.4% walked. About 1.2% used all other forms of transportation
column11: bicycle
column12: and motorcycle. About 3.1% worked at home. The city of Baton Rouge has a higher than average percentage of households without a car. In 2015
column13: 10.4 percent of Baton Rouge households lacked a car
column14: and increased slightly to 11.4 percent in 2016. The national average is 8.7 percent in 2016. Baton Rouge averaged 1.55 cars per household in 2016
column15: compared to a national average of 1.8.
